text: Hello, Octopus, and welcome to the fourth Active Inference Symposium.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thank you for joining us.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're looking forward to your session titled Cognitive Bifurcations and Mathematical Explorations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in case you need a reminder of what the abstract for this talk was, and I had to look this up this morning, thinkers and thoughts have a co-evolutionary relationship.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This relationship is especially clear in the arena of mathematics, where mathematicians forage for mathematical statements and structures in a process governed by complex and potentially unstable rules.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We will give a partial mapping of the structure of this space, which necessarily relies not only on rigorous mathematical logic, but also on subjective beliefs, metacognitive heuristics, and creative play.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I've done a magic trick here.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: All of these things are claims that are in need of evidence from my perspective, and the goal here will be to
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: provide some evidence in that direction, but also to engage in conversation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So in the construction of expertise, I have no ambition here to play the role of expert.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There are certainly qualifications and evidence that I could point to, my experience as a math professor for seven and a half years, my lived experience as a neurodivergent individual for 42 years,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: my my time spent in an octopus identity for the last three years openly and none of those things makes what i say here more valuable than what you think about them the only request i will make is that i've given a lot of effort into thinking through these thoughts some of which were quite difficult that showed up for me and i ask that you will give some level of effort towards finding the value in those thoughts and how they can be mapped to your reality
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Let's move from the abstract to abstraction.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: When people think of mathematics in the modern sense, they often begin here as both its value and its difficulty.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We might imagine that Bob and Alice both have some cows.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Bob has two and Alice has three, and they're curious how many cows they would have if they combined their herd.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Alice can bring her cows to Bob and they can count them then if they have the physical process of counting at their disposal.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: a cognitive tool of one-to-one mapping between objects and objects, but they can also do it conceptually.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One of the things that abstraction enables is the ability to move information about physical perceptions more quickly than the physical things themselves can move.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: In other words, Alice doesn't have to bring her cows with her.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If she can bring the concept of three or the idea that she has three,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this is another aspect of mathematics that is often highly valued and highly contentious in relation to the ways in which we realize and reify scientific practice, education, and other ways in which mathematics shows up in our lives is how are we actually giving a physical body to the concept that we are hoping to represent?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The fact that two apples are conceptually in some sense the same as two cows or two fingers is one level.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A level above that is the fact that we can attribute symbols to these representations.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Anything from two interlaced I's in the Roman numeral setting, to two in the Hindu Arabic numeral setting, to words like to and do, to two dots, to two fingers.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Two fingers are physical, yet somehow they're also a basis of abstraction, because the idea of abstraction includes the fact that there must be something concrete to abstract.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this two fingers are included on the page of abstract representations, partially because I like the idea of things having bodies.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I like the idea of the number two having lots of different bodies.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: How many bodies can one idea have?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But also I like the ambiguity here between the two and the three, because in some systems, the way that I'm showing this here would be interpreted as three and in others as two.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So with that ambiguity in mind, there is no slide three.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Please do not discuss slide three later.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We will not bring it up again.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in fact, it is not advantageous to you to do so because the claim that there is no slide three is an idea wholly owned by eight arms, nine brains.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if you want to discuss the fact that there is no slide three, there will be a licensing fee involved.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Thankfully, some ideas are open to discussion with no financial transaction involved.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And one of them, as we finally come to slide four, is a very important concept in mathematical pedagogy
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: called The Rule of Four.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I think this encapsulates thinking that might have been going on for a while before it was formally published, but the first time I encountered it was in the excellent calculus textbook by Hughes, Hallin, Gleason, and McCollum et al.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This was the first calculus textbook I looked at when I was an undergraduate student.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it was also the first calculus textbook I looked at when I was a beginning professor beginning to teach my first calculus class.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I'm afraid that far too many students probably completely skip this section, which is in the pre preamble.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But one of the key concepts that it elucidates is how to think about mathematics.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it's not saying this is the right way.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's saying this is a way, and this is a way that the textbook uses quite profitably.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's called the rule of four.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it says essentially that when you encounter a new mathematical concept, there are four distinct but interrelated ways that one might think about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You could give a verbal description or a definition.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You could draw a graph or some type of diagram.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You could use numbers in the sense of data.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Or you could use a symbolic representation, like a formula or an equation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the extent to which these are distinct and interrelated highlights the value that each of these may have to individuals as a latching on point for thinking about difficult mathematical concepts and calculus.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It also eliminates some of the privilege that might exist around specific representations, around the idea that symbols might be real math, whereas when we explain them at a high level, somehow that isn't real math.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For instance, if we look at the types of mathematical works that mathematicians actually produce, it might be surprising to undergraduate students what percentage of this is not what they would traditionally think of as symbolic.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And what I would mean here is,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: equations and formulas like we get to page three and finally we see something that looks like a symbolic mathematical expression but the majority of the work here is spent on words and diagrams visuals
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A large portion of this is in the theorems, of course, which are something that is a very individual feature of pure mathematics.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But let's not get bogged down there.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Let's simply say there are many different representations.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And one of the challenges of an effective instructor is to map between these different representations so that people who might feel most at home in one of them can use that as a leverage point for accessing the other ones.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Based on my background, I'm a defrocked math professor voluntarily, also a chaos magician, and so I'm very, very tempted to try to build a functor between this rule of four originating in mathematics and this four-quadrants model of human experience advanced by Ramsey Dukes in his book known as Sysopomy.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: which says that there are these four lenses through which human beings can process and structure experience.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There's art, religion, magic, and science.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's so tempting to try to do something like say the symbols are the magic and the words are the religion and the numbers are the science and the graph is the art.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I'm going to resist that temptation because I think it's
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: it might be a useful initial temptation but the resistance of the temptation provides its value instead i'm going to hold this as an idea we'll return to it in a moment where it will play against some other concepts that we're likely to encounter i will stop here for a moment and say something impromptu though which is um there's a practice in this world of chaos magic called belief shifting
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: where the magician consciously and intentionally adopts a specific belief as if it were something they believed to be true.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And there's a very related practice in mathematics, which is the construction of the axioms or the adoption of the axioms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So in mathematical proofs, once you adopt specific axioms or specific assumptions, the conclusions should follow not without effort, but in a clear logical flow.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Mathematicians are capable of adopting different axioms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this produces what I'm going to call a cognitive bifurcation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So a cognitive bifurcation, since we've already split things into four, that may be too much.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Let's try to get things back together and just split it into two.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One place that a cognitive bifurcation might show up in the history of mathematics is in the different types of geometry that geometers think about.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So one of the features of modern geometry is the realization that the parallel postulate in Euclidean geometry is not possible to prove from the other axioms of Euclidean geometry.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so the parallel postulate says that given a line and a point not on that line,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: there is exactly one parallel line, or there's actually one line that passes through that point parallel to the original line.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if you choose not to adopt this belief, as Riemann played with in the idea of one of his lectures, it opens up a whole new world of non-Euclidean geometry, both spherical and hyperbolic.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the axioms that we adopt and the beliefs that we intentionally choose to consider are powerful tools that can open up new conceptual playgrounds, but also quite dangerous.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Alice and Bob probably feel very safe in this world.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Even if we don't admit a slide three, we admit a number three to describe how many cows one of them may have.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then the question is, are these all the numbers?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if they are not, in which directions would we be willing to consider?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Perhaps we are asking what comes after five or after the number after five.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And like a child, we realize that we can continually add one and there is no a priori upper bound.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we come across the idea of infinity.

text: And so we discover numbers like one and a half or 1.1.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The fact that we can now introduce a number where we add it and identity for the binary operation of addition is an interesting split that opens up more possibilities on the left-hand side.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I would say this is a cognitive bifurcation.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A bifurcation occurs when a small, smooth change made to the parameter values of a system causes a sudden qualitative or topological change in its behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And yet this immense cultural controversy when these numbers are being introduced
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I'm going to make the claim that mathematical thinking systems are complex systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I'm going to give the highly unsatisfactory proof by authority that this claim is obvious.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One piece of evidence we could point to is that the existence of a parameter bifurcation almost immediately suggests that we're dealing with a complex system.

text: And yet that is not quite the right way to think about it, especially if we're going to be looking at it from the active inference context.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What evidence do we see for the belief that mathematical thinking systems are complex systems?

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So it'd be easy to just try to be efficient through this and reduce it as much as we could to something useful.

text: I'm sympathetic to that viewpoint because mathematics has to be useful at some level to human existence to justify its existence, I believe.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if we were looking at this on a belief level, on a probability level, we might say something like with certain axioms as priors,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Mathematical theorems are simply beliefs such that an agent, in order to survive, will quickly adopt correct beliefs with probability 1.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you want to make 2 plus 3 equals 6, you will quickly run into issues in which everything collapses and it ceases to be a useful tool.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I'm not opposed to this model.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I just want to say it's oversimplified.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Because many of the beliefs that mathematicians choose to adopt and choose to spend their valuable resources thinking about don't have any immediate mapping to applications.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For instance, the question of whether or not zero is a natural number is something mathematicians will argue about.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What is the utility in foraging for this belief?

text: Perhaps you can think of one.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But I think it speaks to something else that could be happening that mathematicians throughout the centuries have seen, which is that the claims of truth that you make are not entirely limited by the axioms that you assume and by the process of logic.

text: Mathematicians find it useful to disagree about this.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The conversations that we have about these things make us better mathematicians, I feel.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I'll never forget when my PhD advisor explained to me why he believed that zero was a natural number.

text: But there's no mathematical proof that can provide this.

text: Where does math come from?

text: This is what I've wrestled with a while.

text: One reason is it opens up some doors that from the materialist utilitarian perspective of like a school of engineering feel really strange.

text: So Heinrich Hertz, for whom the unit of cyclic repetition and a computer processing unit is named for, says one cannot escape the feeling that these mathematical formulas
